If you wish to use something like a funnel plot, please instead use Andrews and Kasy 2019 which allows for heterogeniety in the effects themselves. Even AK 2019 is, as I think AK would agree, a first pass at this problem and we should be seeking to improve it! maxkasy.github.io/home/metastu...

Publication bias is probably quite a serious problem, but tests or detection methods for publication bias are in their infancy. We need much more work in this area. As of now, I generally find discontinuities in distributions of t stats to be more convincing than skewness.

I also have more general doubts about the paper as the authors say that they fit the normal in their analysis (figure 7) by "grid search". This is not how we fit simple distributions in stats; we use MLE or Bayesian estimation. The paper on the whole does not appear credible work, to me.

Their figure 3, they claim, shows that RCT estimates of returns to education also do not exhibit the skew. Look at figure 3. It is, in fact, skewed. ehes.org/wp/EHES_249.... Whoever fit that curve to it did not do an amazing job.

On twitter, one of the authors argued that the positive skew was bias because mincerian regression results do not exhibit it (their figure 2). But that figure is in log wages, not rates of returns. The log expands the space near zero and compresses the space in the upper tail, de-skewing the results

In terms of returns to education, it is likely that there is large heterogeneity, and we should expect that if screening is working (by students or by institutions) we see large positive skew in the wild. So using positive skew as indicative of pub bias in this case is quite a reach.

The majority of meta-analysis is unfortunately done cookbook style from the cochrane handbook which focuses on "fixed effects" aggregation, which are only optimal if there is a single effect (no heterogeneity). Once we go to random effects or heirarchical models, tho, we have to choose distribution.

This pre-testing actually does mess up classical stats, but so does like basically everything, so that's a separate issue for another time. I want to stick to issues that arise even in bayesian settings. The skewness of the effects distribution -- or lack of it -- is a big call in any meta-analysis.

Some effects are literally bounded below, and we must expect skewness. Other effects are simply more likely to be positive because of pre-screening, eg, mass rollouts of vaccines or supplements or bed nets only happen after testing the technology first in a hospital or factory

I am generally opposed to funnel plot logic for this reason. However, it is absolutely true that skewness in the distribution of results can be a marker of publication bias. Unfortunately, it can also arise if the distribution of true effects really is skewed, which can happen in a few ways.

The drama occurs about this paper. The claim is that the estimates in figure 7 should be normally distributed. Claims like this -- which underly Funnel plots as well -- usually are underpinned by an assumption of a single estimand, subject only to gaussian sampling error. ehes.org/wp/EHES_249....

Much brouhaha about publication bias online! This could be a good thing, but will in fact for the most part be a frustrating thing, or at least has been so far. Each of us have moments of hubris, when our reach exceeds our grasp. If we are lucky we withdraw our hand, anguished but unharmed, but sometimes the Gods take notice of our arrogance, and, fixing their gaze upon us, intone: “Rate limit exceeded.”

Half sunk, a shattered visage lies, whose frown
And wrinkled lip, and sneer of cold command
Tell that its sculptor well those passions read
Which yet survive, stamped on these lifeless things
The hand that mocked them and the heart that fed
And on the pedestal these words appear: Rate Limit Exceeded
